key_points: The IRS has sent over 163 million third stimulus payments since March, including recent 'plus-up payments'.
The third stimulus checks are based on the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021, signed into law by President Joe Biden on March 11.
Individuals and families may receive up to $1,400 per qualifying member, including adult and child dependents.
Income limits for full payments start phasing out at $75,000 for single filers, $150,000 for married filing jointly, and $112,500 for heads of household.
Payments phase out completely at $80,000 for single taxpayers, $160,000 for married taxpayers filing jointly, and $120,000 for heads of household.
Adult dependents, including college students and disabled adults, are eligible for $1,400, subject to phaseouts.
Eligibility for the stimulus payments is based on the most recent tax return on file (2019 or 2020) with the IRS.
The IRS is issuing 'plus-up payments' to those who qualify for a higher payment based on their 2020 tax returns.
Payments are distributed in weekly batches, with direct deposits and mailed checks ongoing since March 17.
There is currently no indication from President Biden that a fourth stimulus check will be issued.
